title: Marius Sandvei
text:
Marius Sandvei (15 January 1905 – 1 November 1993) was a Norwegian linguist, educator and language politician. He is particularly known for his long-term editing of the <a href="Norwegian%20language">Norwegian</a> normative dictionary "<a href="Tanums%20store%20rettskrivningsordbok">Tanums store rettskrivningsordbok</a>".
Sandvei was born in <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a> as the son of police officer Ole Sandvei and Johanne Sæther. He <a href="Examen%20artium">finished</a> his secondary education in Trondheim in 1924, and graduated from the <a href="University%20of%20Oslo">Royal Frederick University</a> in 1930, his main subject being the <a href="Norwegian%20language">Norwegian language</a>. In 1930 he also married Antonette Kristine Nielsen. He lectured in Norwegian language and literature in Berlin (1930-1931) and Stockholm (1931-1935). From 1935 he taught at the <a href="Trondheim%20Cathedral%20School">Trondheim Cathedral School</a>. From 1946 he was <a href="head%20teacher">head teacher</a> of secondary schools, first in <a href="Kristiansund">Kristiansund</a>, and from 1955 to 1975 at <a href="Grefsen">Grefsen</a>.
Sandvei took an active role in the debates surrounding the formation and maintenance of the <a href="Norwegian%20language">Norwegian language</a>. He issued the Norwegian grammar "" in German in 1934, and the dictionary "Svensk-norsk ordbok" in 1936. He is particularly well known for his role as editor of the normative dictionary "Norsk rettskrivningsordbok", which had been initiated by philologist <a href="Jakob%20Sverdrup%20%28philologist%29">Jakob Sverdrup</a>. When Sverdrup died in 1938, Sandvei took over as editor, and the dictionary was published in 1940. Later editions of the dictionary were called "<a href="Tanums%20store%20rettskrivningsordbok">Tanums store rettskrivningsordbok</a>", and often referred to as "Tanum" or "Sverdrup-Sandvei". Sandvei was a member of the <a href="Norwegian%20Language%20Council">Norwegian Language Council</a> () from its foundation in 1952 to 1959. He participated in the development of a revised textbook norm in 1959.
Sandvei was a member of Kristiansund city council, and was a parliamentary ballot candidate from the Oslo constituency in <a href="1957%20Norwegian%20parliamentary%20election">1957</a> and <a href="1961%20Norwegian%20parliamentary%20election">1961</a>. In Kristiansund he also chaired the local branches of <a href="Rotary%20International">Rotary</a> and <a href="Foreningen%20Norden">Foreningen Norden</a>. He was a central board member of the <a href="Norwegian%20Association%20of%20Graduate%20Teachers">Norwegian Association of Graduate Teachers</a>.
He died in November 1993 in Oslo. After Sandvei's death, <a href="Boye%20Wangensteen">Boye Wangensteen</a> took over as main editor for the 8th edition of "Tanum", published in 1996, and also the 9th edition from 2005.
